title: 112_hr2987
content: The Act titled "American Export Promotion and Job Creation Act" improves coordination of export promotion activities among federal agencies. Section 2312 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to review proposed annual budgets of agencies before submission to the Office of Management and Budget and the President. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include provisions for conducting reviews, developing plans, and issuing executive orders and regulations to ensure the Trade Policy Coordinating Committee (TPCC) fulfills its duties. The term 'small business' is defined within this section. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include provisions for the Trade Policy Coordinating Committee (TPCC) to fulfill its duties. The term 'small business' is defined as a small business concern under the Small Business Act. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DEPLOYMENT OF U.S. COMMERCIAL SERVICE RESOURCES. Section 2301(c)(4) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the Secretary to conduct a global assessment of overseas markets to increase US exports and redeploy Commercial Service personnel and resources accordingly. The Secretary is required to conduct a global assessment of overseas markets to increase US exports and redeploy Commercial Service personnel and resources accordingly every 5 years. Additionally, the Secretary must provide requested assistance upon request. SEC. 4. STRENGTHENED U.S. COMMERCIAL DIPLOMACY IN SUPPORT OF U.S. EXPORTS. Development of a plan for effective diplomacy to remove obstacles to exports of US goods and services, in consultation with relevant stakeholders, is required under the Foreign Service Act. The chief of mission must submit the plan to the Secretary for review before implementation. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 requires the development of a commercial diplomacy plan to promote US exports. Assessments of the plan's effectiveness in promoting exports must be conducted for members of the Service with economic responsibilities. Additionally, the Inspector General will assess the effectiveness of commercial diplomacy efforts. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 mandates a commercial diplomacy plan to boost US exports. Assessments of its effectiveness for members with economic roles will be conducted, along with an evaluation by the Inspector General.
